title: Microscopic and Elemental Characterization of PLLA Functionalized with Electrosynthetized AgNPs
content: Surgical site infections in orthopedic implant-related procedures are an important public health problem that increases mobility and mortality around the world [1, 2]. To overcome this worldwide phenomenon, antibiotic prophylaxis of implants and design of antimicrobial biomaterials are necessary to prevent post-surgical infections. This situation is exacerbated by the fast generated bacterial resistance against antibiotics by pathologic microorganisms of the hospital environment. A promising strategy against this relevant issue is the use of antimicrobial coatings, such as silver nanoparticles (AgNPs), a plausible choice since its effectiveness as a growth inhibitor has been widely studied [2-4]. L-polylactic acid (PLLA) is a biopolymer that is very used in the orthopedic field [5-8], and the functionalization of this compound with AgNPs is a promising choice in the design and manufacture of antimicrobial biomaterials.
